I've learned so much about the phenomenon from so many sources, but I first learned about it, many years ago, from someone who worked at an infertility clinic, and I've never stopped listening to clinic workers talking about it.

@lamacurieux @elibyronbaldrsn @spmcdonnell @SocialistVampyr @morrigan2k Like, I'm sure that you know there are far more than just two genital configurations in humans, for example, but that doesn't mean it's not worth looking at in more depth as a part of this discussion.

@liminalfruitbat @AnaMardoll @weird_cowgirl @iridienne To be clear, the word translated as "men" means "humans", where the word translated as "mankind" means "our"/"of ourselves".

It says the Egyptian gods were overpowered by the multitude and lawlessness of earth-born _humans_, and saved themselves from _our_ savagery and violence.

@weird_cowgirl Ok, diving deeper, it's worth noting that "of earth born men" would be more accurately translated "earth born humans" as it specifically uses the Greek word for human instead of the world for male human.

As for "mankind" it literally says "ourselves" there.

@liminalfruitbat @AnaMardoll @weird_cowgirl @iridienne Damn it.  "Antrhopon" and "andron".

The letter nu looks like a v, and every so often I transcribe it that way even as I'm thinking of it as sounding like an "n".
@liminalfruitbat @AnaMardoll @weird_cowgirl @iridienne It says humans.  Anthropov not androv.  There's nothing subtle about it whatsoever. https://t.co/uMr8CzIbsF

@weird_cowgirl @AnaMardoll @iridienne The fact that the preview page doesn't actually say which book it's a preview _of_ is frustrating, but unless Loeb had two widely excerpted 1933 translations of "The Library of History"/"Bibliotheca Historica", it's a fair bet it's Oldfather's translation.

@AnaMardoll The degree to which I call bullshit cannot be overstated.
@AnaMardoll Anyway, that's my "I didn't realize racism was still a thing for a disturbingly long time, and as someone who's lived that, I still call bullshit in this instance" thing.
@AnaMardoll And also just: racism is more visible to its targets than it is those who are not targeted.

@AnaMardoll I white person surrounded almost exclusively by other white people doesn't see much interracial interaction, a non-white person surrounded almost exclusively by white people can't escape it.

These are not remotely the same thing, and there's no way they lead to the same place.

@AnaMardoll As someone who grew up in one of the really white parts of Maine; that can really fuck with your perception, but I cannot _imagine_ that fuckery going in the same direction for BIPOC growing up in a place like this.

@AnaMardoll It's possible some recent trends I haven't kept up with have changed this, but if we're talking about 1997 that's not relevant, so...

Whether Vermont or Maine is the whitest state in America usually depends on crunchy details, because they've basically neck and neck for ages.

@AnaMardoll >at 16 years old, genius though she is, she "didn't yet understand racism".

I just... no.  Can this be true at 16?  Yes; if you're a white American, it can absolutely be true.  Not sure how the fuck a person of color growing up in one of the two whitest states could pull it off.

@AnaMardoll Are the police vampires?

Because otherwise them not going in for lack of initiation doesn't sound like any American cops I've ever heard of outside of the most saccharine fantasy, and given that this book posits that everyone with a Y chromosome is inherently evil . . . yeah.

And then I spent God knows how long not doing anything about the rat problem because of depression.

The rats chewed a hole through the basement door the size of a small window, and without that plastic sheet in place, air from outside was able to freely mix with air inside.

That's where the basement door is, though, and I was frequently going in there to check that the rats weren't getting through the door.

I'm not sure if I left it uncovered because I figured I'd check again soon anyway, or because I forgot, or what.

I just know it wasn't sealed.

Fortunately, one can just close the door, and in so doing keeping the cold as fuck air in there from mixing with the air in the rest of the house.

Under the master bedroom is more difficult, as there isn't a door.  To keep that cold air out, I'd sealed it off with plastic sheet.

So, here's where I tell you about my house.  As much as I love it, it's not the best built thing.  One particular example of this is the master bedroom, which is an addition.  Short version: it's not insulated.

In fucking Maine.

Though dealing with the food hasn't helped with my depression, because keeping everything in rat resistant containers makes food preparation harder.

It's easier to make food when you can just reach into your cabinets, but those fuckers eat through the wall and devour stuff.

This did not help with the rat problem.

I suppose I'm really lucky to have gotten all of the food dealt with before everything went so wrong.

The guy from the city stopped coming in 2021.

For over a year --the end of 2020, the whole of 2021, and the beginning of 2022-- I was barely able to drag myself out of bed, plop myself in a chair for the day, and --if I was lucky-- maybe get up to eat and drink on occasion.

With first three children and then one child to care for, my mom didn't have time to come here anymore.

I went from frequent positive in person human contact to no in person human contact.

It was like the bottom dropped out from under me, and depression just took over.

My mom is very fit and very spry, but 2020 is the year she turned seventy.  Three kids was too much for her.  She ended up just caring for the eldest, and sweet fuck is there a story behind all of that, but it's not relevant to this thread.

I'm sure you can tell that didn't happen.

On the day my mom was coming down to rent the truck, with my mom in her car on her way to my house, my mom got a phone call.

The police had sent my sister to the psyche ward, and my mom was being called to take care of her kids.

Emotionally, this was the best I'd been in a long time, probably because of consistent human contact that didn't suck.

My mom was gonna rent a truck to deal with the big items, and then we'd turn from the stuff housemate houseguest threw out to the stuff they organized and...

We went through everything housemate and houseguest had thrown out, we removed all outside food for rats, we found so much of my cookware.  (I was looking forward to being able to cook again.)

All that was left outside were a few big items.

Now, I pay all of the expenses on the property, but I don't own my house; my mom does.

In part because of that, and in part just to help, my mom came by to help me deal with this shit.

And it went well.  Really well.  Felt like by the end of 2020 all would be unfucked.

8 He'd ignore all of my attempts to reach him.

9 Nothing bad would happen.

10 With the urgency gone, and it possibly already too late, my depression would take over and I wouldn't be able to work.

Then we'd restart all the way back at one.  For months.

(3/3)

(2/3)

That started a sequence that would go like this:

1 He'd show up, give scary ultimatums that would kick my anxiety into too high a gear to function

2 After a while I'd regain the ability to function, and start working on the problem

(1/3)

She moved out at the start of September.  By the end, a man from the city had come knocking about the rats.  A rat haven is a public health hazard, and sweet fuck had my property been transformed into a rat haven.

So the cat was the reason I finally made housemate leave.  Not that she'd thrown out so much of my stuff, not because that combined with the food she and houseguest left out lead to the rats gnawing holes in my walls, not so many other things.

We got the cat when we were still a "we".  My mom and I were still living together in the house I grew up in.  When she moved to live with her boyfriend, the cat stayed with me.  For the longest time it was just us, and bitey gecko that never leaves his tank (because :bitey.)

I honestly hadn't been sure if that was possible for me.  No matter how bad things ever got, the concept of suicide always threw a divide by cheese error.

Then, suddenly, it didn't.  It didn't last long, though it wouldn't be the last time, and I certainly didn't act on it.

I wanted to search for the cat, I wanted to put up fliers, I wanted to try to find her.  I couldn't make myself do anything.  Depression fucking sucks.

When it really sunk in that the cat was gone and I'd done _nothing_, for the first time I wanted to kill myself.
Housemate hadn't seen the cat the entire time I was gone.  Housemate had not thought this was worth telling me.  This even though she was supposed to watch Chloe and the cat.

Technically the cat's name was Pandora, but I never really called her that, and the situation was more like the nameless cat in Breakfast at Tiffany's or, say, a timelord named The Cat.

Anyway, I asked housemate about the cat.

When I got back, my cat was missing.

She was obviously near the end of her life, and frail, and I knew that continuing to let her out might be a mistake, but being outside seemed to be one of the few things she enjoyed, so I risked it.

So I asked housemate about the cat.

The story is a good deal more fraught than that, but that's the basic outline.

Then I went to my sister's, even though I didn't want to, because she thought she might be in danger and thought another adult being present would prevent it.

She was wrong.  More trauma.

Housemate and houseguest had an incredibly messy falling out, and each accused the other of stealing my Adderall (which I had noticed seemed to be getting used up faster than it should.)

And that culminated in houseguest leaving.
So, I now had a dog, and trauma, and two people living with me, and rats.

... in spite of my life since then being a series of financial near catastrophes, it was worth it.

After watching her get hit, I couldn't just let her die.

She's sleeping like six feet to my right right now.  She made a full recovery in less than a week.
I promised her that if she lived, I'd keep her forever.  The medical care put me into a financial situation I still haven't managed to crawl out of, and everyone told me to just let her die, but...

...was worried that I might not be taking good enough care of my cat, but my sister said if I didn't take Chloe, she'd be forced to put her down.  With a shotgun.

So I agreed to take care of Chloe until a new owner could be found.  Then she got hit by a car.

Around this time I also got one addition that wasn't terrible.  Chloe used to be my sister's dog.  She's the dog who had puppies when my sister was in the hospital.

I didn't really think I was in a good place for caring for a dog, and...

Mostly, though, they left plates of food everywhere.

Regardless, they left out food, and the rats came.

Rats are smart, resourceful, tenacious, and possessed with teeth like unto tiny mutant attack beavers.

At night you could hear them gnawing through the walls.

Fuck, they dirtied every cup in the house, and switched to mason jars, and then dirtied all of those because it was easier to leave a mason jars with tasty rat-friendly beer around the house than it was to actually fucking wash a glass or a cup.

And, with such a wonderful feast outside, they naturally decided to poke around inside.

Housemate and houseguest were not clean people.

I never leave food out.  They left food out everywhere.

So, the thing about the lockdown is that when restaurants shut down, the rats who depended on their food waste branched out into the suburbs.

And the rats that ventured into my neighborhood, they found wonderful bags of trash, just waiting for them to investigate.

With everyone saying not to get on a plane, houseguest couldn't leave.  I was trapped with him.

Also, I didn't want to hold "I can evict you" over anyone's head, which . . . which made me refuse to consider the obvious solution to two people ransacking my house.

And they rather emphatically did not stop at the kitchen.  On a day when I had energy I tried to supervise one room, but the stress and overstimulation was too much.

At around this time, the pandemic happened.
So now I had dig through the trash to recover important things (who throws out someone else's appliances and savings bonds?) which meant that the trash had to wait for me to go through it.

One can make an argument that some of those things shouldn't have been in the kitchen, but they definitely didn't belong in the trash.

And the thing about the trash is: it's the trash.

Trash for a house that now had three people.

See, by "clean" they meant "throw out everything" which is a problem when "everything" includes one's cookware, blender, convection oven, silverware, cutlery, pots, pans, photographs, tarot cards, hard drive, cups, glasses, and so forth.

And this is where we get to what this whole ordeal has to do with rats eating through my basement door causing me to burn through heating oil way faster than expected making me run out at what appears to be the literal worst possible time.

On the day he arrived I had so little energy I seriously couldn't make myself stand up, which left me listening to housemate and houseguest "clean the kitchen" while not being about to _do_ anything.

The kitchen, I note, is not the basement.

A giant fricking machine had to be used.  Again, this was the least accessible part of the basement.

This meant moving furniture and shit, and housemate thought it would a three person job.

Enter houseguest.

Anyway, my sister's dog had puppies, my sister got out the hospital, life went on, and eventually the fact something was wrong became unmissable.

So I made a path, we got a plumber, and it turned out that, because the clog was more than six feet outside of the house . . .

Now that I had one of those, the hole made a sort of release valve that prevented us from noticing the clog for a while.  If that hadn't been the absolute least accessible part of the basement, probably would have noticed sooner.

The hole was at the end of the interior sewer pipe, meaning that only a clog outside the house (in the underground pipe that connected my house to the public sewer, could cause a backup that would make water/filth/whatever come out of the hole

I managed to get the noticeable clog out, but I didn't know that further down the line there was a hole in a pipe.  It had probably been there for at least a decade, but gravity kept it from ever being a problem.

The paper towels changed that.

Which meant that housemate was at the house with no toilet paper.  She used paper towels.

As a public service announcement:
Don't flush paper towels.  Not ever.

I dropped everything to go see my sister, though I think I ended up spending more time housesitting for her than I did in the hospital.

Housemate, tired to, on the grounds that getting run over trumps any animosity, but that didn't work out.

I don't regret that, but I do regret a fuckton of things that happened as a result of that.

A notable one being the rats.  That's getting ahead of myself, though.  First two things happened.

First, the house ran out toilet paper, second my sister got run over by her truck.

I live in the house I grew up in, which housed a family of four when I was growing up.  I had space to offer.  So I did.  I convinced my sister to wait on the ride that was coming for me the next day, and I let housemate move in with me.

Her relationship with her housemate had turned toxic, and they both wanted it to end. My sister wanted to kick housemate right then, and housemate was calling everyone she knew begging for a ride out of there so she could be homeless in Portland instead of staying with my sister.

Now, I'd probably have to write a novel to get you up to date on my sister, but for the moment all you need to know is that in late 2019 I went up to her house for a weekend to help with . . . I don't even know, and it didn't get done regardless.

Going off my hormones fucked me up, going back on them didn't fix things.  So by late 2019 I was already in the midst of a period where my depression would be the worst it had ever been for months, and then get even worse, thus redefining what "worst" meant.

Ok, so, a day late, but let's try the long version.

Part of the reason that it's the long version is that it starts in late 2019, though one could make an argument for when I broke my angle in Feb. 2017 and had to go off my hormones because of the ankle surgery.

Ok, so, when one sees an article with the title:

> Invisible fridges and cooling cubbies: how kitchens have been designed for the rich

one does not expect to learn about a lauded white American feminist wanting to - as noted by Ana - re-enslave black people https://t.co/iOBCpzS9wA
Part of the reason I decided to write this before getting the diesel is that four days ago my plan was "get diesel then try to fundraise" and it didn't exactly work out that way.

Until I can order oil and have it delivered, I'll be depending on diesel from half a mile down the road.

I actually pay road taxes on it, because none of the gas stations in walking distance have off-road diesel.

There's more going on than just that, but that's the end of the somewhat longer version.

The long version will follow later in the day.  I wanted to get this out, and the temperature is above freezing so writing this first didn't risk any pipes bursting, but it's cold in here.

Which is what allowed them to eat a hole in the basement door the size of a small window without me noticing.

Depression is also the reason that I'm writing this today, when the price of 100 gallons of heating oil (minimum order) is $529 instead of 4 days ago when it was $449.

I knew that the basement door was a problem, and I had been keeping track of it and making sure they weren't gnawing through it, but at some point my depression deepened so that basically all I can do is eat, drink, sleep (rarely in the proper amounts) and sit at the computer...

. . . after I locked down all the food.

They do damage, and they constantly try to find food (sometimes getting into non-food like hand soap and, oddly enough, rat poison), but it's not the fucking siege it was back before I managed to make all food storage ratproof.

...

. . . means that for a year and 4ish months I've done very little to address the rat problem.

For the most part, this has not been as bad as it may sound.  There's no food for them here, which means that I've basically just got stragglers who decided to keep nesting here . . .

In November 2020, I lost my only in person source of human contact.  As a result, other than when I get a ride to buy food, which about once a month, I never see or talk to anyone.  I only interact via text over the internet.

This made my depression worse, and . . .

Somewhat longer version: Rats and depression

I burned through my heating oil way faster than expected because rats chewed a hole through my basement door, and I might as well have had a window open for however long that hole has been there.

As for depression...

So please, for the sake of fuck, don't use this unjust, downright fucking evil, invasion as an excuse for anti-Russian prejudice.

The people you'll hurt aren't the ones responsible, and you'll _never_ manage to hurt the ones who are.

Hating Russians will do nothing to help the people of Ukraine, because the problem isn't Russians.

Vladimir Putin did not personally consult every Russian/non-Russian with Russian ancestry before launching this invasion, and the random Russian you might mistreat cannot stop it.

Russia covers more than 11% of the world's landmass, and Putin can't even stamp out dissent in the urban area of Moscow, which covers 0.0039%.

It should go without saying that Russians are not all the same.  For some reason it doesn't.  As such: Russians are not all the same.

Right now, the person who voiced Paddington Bear in the Ukrainian dub is leading his country in a fight against the largest nation on earth.

So, consider two things:
1 People are more than stereotypes, and more is possible than you know
2 Russia is too big to paint with 1 brush.
Given that the reasons get more minor as the list goes on, I'm gonna stop listing them.

Third, if one is seriously inexorably compelled to something, and none of the usual stuff (donations, signal raising, agitating for their country to accept refugees, so forth) is cutting it, there is actually a (terrifying and high risk) thing able bodied people can do.

If that last bit seems glib, sorry, but I'm saying it for a lot of reasons.

First off, they really do need people.

Second, I have a hard time believing anyone can find literally nothing to do save for be a bigot toward Russians.

(continued)

They also need people who can fight, so if you should be so powerfully overcome with the need to do something that you cannot refrain, you can always talk to the Ukrainian embassy and start on your way to holding a Kalashnikov in Ukraine.

I get how hard it is when you feel helpless to do anything, but that doesn't excuse being a terrible person.

Ukraine doesn't need us to make ourselves into bigots.  They need us to take in refugees, provide aid and, if it can be done without starting WWIII, set-up a no-fly zone.

Thousands of Russians have been arrested by Putin's government for the "crime" of protesting against the invasion.

You do no one any favors when you assume that to be Russian is to be like Putin instead of to be like them.

Justice can't be reduced to prejudice.

If all you have to offer is indiscriminate hate, you will never be on the side of good.

When people reduced all of WWII, Holocaust included, to "German speakers bad" they further hurt the Nazis victims while patting themselves on the back for standing up to Nazis.

That's not surprising.  In fact, it was basically inevitable the moment they chose to embrace bigotry.

You've probably heard that story before, even though I don't think I've told it before.

You've probably heard it because it's incredibly common.  It happened so many times to so many people.

Well before I was born, my dad had a job doing upkeep at some apartment building.

One time people asked him which apartment he was going to, and when he answered they said that it was the Nazi bastard's apartment.

When the man let him in, my dad saw the number on his arm.

I have a friend --from Indonesia, if it matters-- who says that the anti-Russian bigotry reminds him of the post 9/11 islamophobia.

He's right.  It's the same damned thing.  Something terrible was done, people are using it as an excuse for bigotry.
Hurting people who happen to share their nationality and/or language does not punish or deter the oligarchs responsible for this invasion.

If you can find literally nothing to do in response to the invasion of Ukraine save for fucking with unrelated Russians: Do.  Fucking.  Nothing.

Your desire to feel like you're doing something does not outweigh other people's right to not be harassed.

Lashing out at ordinary Russians will not help the people of Ukraine.

Being an asshole to people of Russian ancestry will not help Ukraine or its people.

I hope that no one who follows me needs to be told this, but just in case:

Russia doing something bad does not mean that Russians are bad.  Russia doing something bad does not give you an excuse to mistreat Russians.

@MockRamblings As a last thing, the absolute mess that is the relationship between English spelling and pronunciation will never be fixed.

There are ~160 English dialects, and God knows how many accents, and fixing English spelling would require declaring that all but one of them are wrong.

@MockRamblings Most of the what the brought up was regarding potato, which I've obviously forgotten given that I don't even remember which absurd spelling of potato it was.

For fish, the short version is that  "gh" for "f" is only for syllable coda, while "ti" for "sh" is only syllable onset.

@MockRamblings I remember someone encountering the 19th century "ghoti" spells "fish" meme for the first time along with, I think, an absurd spelling for potato and then destroying in a way I never could because, where I knew such phonetics as specials cases, they actually knew the rules.

@MockRamblings It's also worth noting that, even when there are hard and fast rules, most fluent English-as-first-language speakers have no idea what those rules are.

One of the wonders of a first language is that you don't have to understand how it works, because it's become ingrained in you.

America, like Maine, needs actual leadership right now.  We've been in crisis for over a year.

For the the reconciliation bill, Democrats are kowtowing to Manchin and Sinema, but your vote counts just as much as either of theirs.

Any time there's a 50 vote threshold, you could be the one shaping policy instead of one of them, rather than being disregarded.

With the filibuster, there's little room for you, personally, to make a difference; you don't have ten votes to give.

If the filibuster is abolished, however, one or two Republicans can make all the difference in the world.

You, and possibly Sen. Murkowski, could lead the way.

We live in incredibly difficult times.  In the absence of federal leadership, over half a million Americans have died of COVID-19, almost 95% of them unnecessarily.

The Post Office used to be the single most reliable part of the Federal Government and the only part that had near universal approval.

The reason it's self-funding instead of using taxes was to insulate it from politics; what's happening now is entirely political.

In fact, the darkly comic twist on it is that I was denied on the basis of not returning the paperwork _before_ the paperwork even reached me.

To return it on time I'd have needed a time machine.

Also last week I got a letter saying that I'd been denied benefits (just food stamps; I still have healthcare) for not returning paperwork on time.

That letter was absurdly late in arriving, but not nearly so late as the paperwork in question had been.

Late last week, my mom told me that a friend of hers contacted her to let her know that the Christmas card she sent them had arrived.

My mom's a retired letter carrier; she knows how hectic things get circa-Christmas.  She sent it early enough that it had no business being late.
On Monday, I got a package that was sent on November 11th.  Ten days shy of four months for a shipment that should have been a week or less.

They asked that they be contacted within seven days of receiving the letter if there had been a problem.

Something tells me they didn't realize that would work out to almost a month after they sent it.

There wasn't a problem, so I'm fine on that front, but damn.

A day or two ago, I got a letter from the IRS.  It was about the $600 stimulus payment.  The message was basically, "If you don't have the money yet, something definitely went wrong, and you should contact us about it soon."

They sent it on February 15th.
I wanna talk about the Post Office, but rather than directly say that DeJoy is evil and needs to go, I'm gonna be paraphrastic about it.

So, in closing, it wasn't Neanderthal thinking, it was asshole thinking in the traditional stylings of Homo sapiens sapiens.

Cut Neanderthals some slack. They did nothing to you, nor do we know of any bad shit they did to anyone else, and you might be a bit Neanderthal yourself.

Like I said, this is something that's been on my mind since I was a child, and the things I've learned since then as science has uncovered more and more about Neanderthals has done nothing to change that.

Maybe they were horrible people who deserve all the modern bullshit, but the evidence we have doesn't so much as _suggest_ that.

So far as we know, they did absolutely nothing to merit constantly insulting them some 40,000 years after they were dead and gone.

This is probably something no one else cares about —Neanderthals don't exist anymore, and the vast majority of their descendants neither know nor care that the are— but since I was a child it's always bothered me that we're constantly insulting people we know next to nothing of.

Anyway, the Republican Party is entirely composed of Homo sapiens sapiens, and leaving the less fortunate to die en masse is, unfortunately, something that's very common for modern humans.

Governor Abbots decision wasn't Neanderthal thinking, it's entirely on our own species.

When I tried to look up how many of us are a bit Neanderthal, I came across something else.  Certain Neanderthal genes (from the vicinity of what's now Bangladesh) are associated with getting severely fucked up by COVID-19.

I understand what Biden meant, but I've honestly never been very comfortable with all the dunking on Neanderthals.  We don't actually know a damned thing about their decision making abilities (only their crafting abilities) and a fuckton of modern humans are part Neanderthal.

Others voted for it and supported it.  Most of them still support it.

I don't know what to do, but I do know that it starts with remembering that it didn't have to be this way.

Something else --something far, far better-- was possible.  The reason we're in this hellscape instead of that better world is that certain people chose this.

The reason we don't is down to politics, and most of the people responsible for those politics are still in office.

Meanwhile, a lot of the people who _should_ be fighting against them are instead obsessed with letting them slide.

I want you to picture a world where the worst of COVID-19 in the US was over by early May 2020, where we're currently averaging 200 new cases a day instead 65,400.  Where new pandemic deaths each day were close to zero, instead of two thousand.

We could have had that world.

So, in closing:
     2,000 + 600 > 2,000

People know that, so if they end up with just two thousand, they'll know that they didn't get what they were promised.

That people meant $2,000 total is a non-issue, because that's not what they said, and thus isn't what they promised.

It's worth noting that Democrats have long had a problem of pre-surrendering instead of fighting.

This isn't just a terrible strategy in terms getting shit done, it's a bad image.  You get way more credit for _trying_ to keep you promises than you do for preemptively conceding.

I get that they meant two thousand dollars total.  Truly, I do.  That's not what they said, though.  More than that, it's not what people voted for.

"Oops, I meant to say and write and and draw, and otherwise indicate something completely unrelated," is not a winning argument

Let this be a lesson to the people who said something they didn't mean.  Actually, let it be two lessons.

Lesson one: Say what you mean.

Lesson two: If you make a promise a thousand times over, people will expect you to keep _that_ promise, not the promise you meant to make.

A lot of people are saying that Biden and the like meant $2,000 total.  That's nice, but largely irrelevant.

With six hundred already sent, they promised a two thousand dollar check, and two thousand plus six hundred is greater than two thousand alone.  This is very basic math.

I don't know who needs to hear this, but I'm a mathematician so listen up.

If you're given $600 dollars, then --with that money already in your bank account-- someone promises you a $2,000 check, and the final result is that you get $2,000 total, that means you got ripped off.

@AnaMardoll Jefferson and the others weren't _just_ slaveholders, they were massive fucking bigots, and they shaped their world and their laws in the service of that.

They saw slavery, which was already something terrible, and they managed to make it worse.

@AnaMardoll Once you decide that someone is subhuman, they've become livestock instead of workers.  You can't let them learn because then you get Animal Farm.

Instead of interbreeding of freed slaves and freeborn white people being natural and expected, it's transformed into bestiality.

@AnaMardoll American slavery, and American culture, was built around the idea that some people can never truly be equal to others.

Everything else flows from that.

@AnaMardoll A key concept from Roman slavery, the idea that all freeborn people in a country were equal members of that country, has been replaced by something far worse.

Racism says that American slaves, former slaves, and their descendants can _never_ be equal.

@AnaMardoll The reasoning basically goes:

If we're better than them, and important shit is inherited, than our kids will be better than their kids, so if our people should be allowed to keep them as slaves (you shouldn't!) we should be able to keep their descendants as slaves.

@AnaMardoll Scientists try to classify different human beings; the concept of race is born.

The scientists who start this aren't actually evil, it should be probably noted.  It takes basically no time flat for evil people to take the idea of race as inheritance and run with it.

@AnaMardoll Fast forward a metric fuckton, and Rome has fallen, Europeans have decided that they don't like it when Europeans are enslaved on a generational basis, and science is trying to classify everything.

@AnaMardoll You get freed and you've got skills as an accountant, or a manager, or a philosopher, or a historian, or whatever the fuck.

You're ready to have the kind of career a regular Roman citizen has, and your kids will _be_ citizens.  Your kids.  One fucking generation to equal rights.

@AnaMardoll US slavery was all about crushing people and making it nigh inconceivable that they could ever have a good life.

Roman slavery was fully ready to crush you if you got out of line, but it was paired with the idea that you could take apart in all the wealth and success you create.

@AnaMardoll The people Jefferson is talking about, though, are only a small part of the difference.  Most people won't be remembered by history as exceptional in their field.

The more significant thing is that, because they were educated, freed Roman slaves were equipped to succeed.

@AnaMardoll You know what happens when you give lots of people PhD level educations over the course of hundreds of years?  Some of them leave impressive marks on history.

There's no fucking racial component to it.  Let people excel, and some of them will.  That's all there is to it.

@AnaMardoll This brings us back to Jefferson and why Roman slaves excelled.

Romans used their slaves to tutor their children.  Romans used their slaves to manage their businesses.  Romans used their slaves to handle the household finances.

@AnaMardoll Many freedmen actually became rich, and we've got some satire surviving that has lower class Romans thumbing their noses at them for being nouveau riche.

The reason for the previous is that Romans wanted their slaves to be productive, so they educated them.

@AnaMardoll So, on that carrot, and on being allowed to excel...

With Roman law and culture crafted to be fairly accepting of freed slaves and completely accepting of their kids, the prospect of being freed meant a fuckton more than just having a less miserable life.

@AnaMardoll Roman slavery functioned on a carrot and stick method.  The carrot was being freed and having any post-freedom children be full citizens.

The stick was being sent to the mines or, if you're part of the Spartacus revolt, being crucified with six thousand of your closest friends.

@AnaMardoll The reason that Roman slaves could integrate into Roman society so well upon being freed was that Roman society was built for that in a way US society refused to be.

The reason that Roman slaves produced so much impressive arts and science shit is that they were _allowed_ to.

@AnaMardoll This is not to say that black Romans necessarily had slavery in their ancestry, but rather that Jefferson's thing about the Romans not having the same problems because they weren't freeing black slaves is bullshit on that level as well.

@AnaMardoll Given interbreeding and cultural assimilation, any experiences they had with this would have seemed to bear that out.

The practical result was that, for all that they were ethnocentric bigots, it never occurred to them to apply that to the Roman descendants of freed slaves.

@AnaMardoll The popular theory at the time was that the reason people from different places looked different was the places, not the people.

Take people out of one place and put them into another, and their descendants will end up looking and acting like the people from the second place.

@AnaMardoll 2/2 ...was that those traits that we associate with races weren't actually seen as inherently as hereditary.

@AnaMardoll Race as a concept hadn't been invented yet.

All of this was completely predictable because of the forces at work right now.

It's economists fucking _job_ to understand those forces.

Why, the fuck, would the have expected a smaller decline?

Which brings us full circle: I think someone somewhere assumed a ladder.

Where else?  Auto dealerships and gas stations.

People who are traveling far less, and have no reason to think that will change any time soon, aren't as enamored with the idea of a new car as they might otherwise be.

People aren't buying shit in the gas stations they're not in.

Where did sales fall?  Restaurants and brick and mortar stores that sell home furnishing and electronics.

People aren't putting themselves at risk of catching a debilitating and sometimes fatal virus to eat out or buy discretionary shit.  Color me surprised.
I kind of distracted myself, though.  The pandemic in general is pretty obvious surface level stuff, but I said it gets stupider when you dig deeper, so let's look at more of that.

For what it's worth, if they'd expected a larger decline, I wouldn't be on their case.

Consider that the only time we had new infections increasing at anywhere near this pace was March and early April.  Those months had declines of 8.2 & 14.7.

You can put this in eleven thousand different contexts, and all of them say that a 1.1% decline in retail sales should not have been a surprise.

November was to October as October was to September.  That would have suggested 1.5 originally, and 1.9 with the revised figures.

Then we get to November which starts with around a hundred thousand people infected a day and ends closer to two hundred thousand.

"Economists had expected a smaller decline [...]"

Even if October had had 0.3% growth like economists had thought (the revised figure is -0.1%) it would be barely scraping by with prosperity borrowed from November and new infections starting at ~40,000 a day and ending closer to 100,000 a day.

Second, November was the month of exponential growth, both in terms of infections and deaths.  It was a raging fucking Hellscape, the likes of which we've never seen before.

Fuck, for new infections it _started_ worse than ever, and had pretty well doubled that by month's end.

So, first off, even sans pandemic, November would have been less Novermbery than usual, because November stuff got pushed into October, leaving less November stuff for November itself.

That means that anyone counting on November's usual effects was missing some key context.

It gets stupider when you dig down deeper.

In an effort to jumpstart holiday spending sprees, retailers pushed annual sales events into October.  (And, lo, did the Grinch steal Halloween.)

This means that people did some November shopping in October, _which is not November_.

Nothing is working and there's no end in sight because those with the power to fix things lack the will, and those with the will lack the power.

Cases are high in 49 states, D.C., and 2 territories.

"Economists had expected a smaller decline [...]"

Change only comes when enough people refuse to accept the way things are, so for a very long time I've wished for this moment. Now that it's here, I'm nothing but afraid.

It was easier when I lived alone. Dying doesn't scare me; people I know getting hurt or killed terrifies me.

And I think about Tiananmen.  My biggest fear is that people will die, nothing will ultimately come of it, and no one will know.

The one night that organizers were pretty fucking sure there would be violence, she stayed home.  That's vaguely reassuring, but violence doesn't always give notice.

Also, she understands the privilege she has as a white kid, but harm isn't always caused on purpose.

I'd like to think that, if my depression weren't leaving me so fucking out of it, she's what I'd be like (just, you know, older and hopefully wiser.)

And just, in general, oh my fucking God this kid is incredible.

I've been researching astrolabes and historical handwriting.  She's been researching how to prepare yourself for tear gas.

My research has been for a My Little Pony fanfic I'm writing.  Hers is for protecting herself and the adults around her.

There's a sizable contrast here.

I also worry about someone else.  Houseguest (arguably housemate 2 at this point) asked if his daughter could come here in the summer.  It must be summer, because she's here.

She's 14, she's smart, she's *so* engaged wrt social justice, and she wants to change the world too.

I am so fucking worried about her.

She's black.  She's a lesbian.  She has a history as a sex worker.  People like her get ignored and forgotten.  There's no national outcry when the police hurt or kill them.

She wants to change the world; I worry she won't come back alive.

I did hear about George Floyd almost immediately, I think.  Not because of the news, because of housemate.

If I hadn't offered her a place to stay here, it's legitimately possible I still wouldn't know about his death or the protests.

I also haven't been keeping up with news.  I've occasionally been looking at what some people who are keeping up with the news are saying about the pandemic, but, in general, I don't think I've been paying attention to the news since Elizabeth Warren dropped out of primary.

When it comes to money, I'm always right at the edge of having everything collapse, I don't really have anything to spare for delivery, but the world is fucked up right now, and compared to the $5,000 I still need for the dog . . . yeah.

I don't even know how often it used to happen, because it was so rare.  Even during most of the past 40 months I don't think it could have been more than once every six months on average, and it was probably far less.

It happened twice last month, and three times in April.

That means that I haven't exactly been keeping up with things.  A concrete example is eating.

There comes a point when the lack of energy from not eating is at a point where I can't get food (if I don't have it) or prepare food (if I do.)

My solution is delivery food.

And you know what?  That didn't bother me.  I knew where she stood.  Then I read her talking about how close she is to Chloe and how Chloe's a best friend and it does bother me.

Today my sister called me and said they wanted to know if I was aware of the plan and the estimated full cost and, if so, if I was willing to pay.

I never expected anything different from her.  She didn't seem to think the $2,085 was worth paying, why would she add more?
I'd been waiting to pay a bit over two thousand dollars that I didn't have so they could start to stabilize Chloe, my sister wasn't even willing to part with basic intake information.

My sister, the legal owner who makes it sound like she's so close to Chloe?  She didn't even want to give the emergency vets any information until she knew she wouldn't pay.

(She was once billed for a stray cat that she brought in that didn't make it, she didn't want a repeat.)

And that's what it has been.  I've paid whatever it cost get her medical care.

Some people are trying to raise funds to help, but so it's just been me.  Two credit cards (that were paid off) are now maxed out.  A third might as well be.  The Paypal donations I got are spent.

I made a promise to Chloe that if she lived, I'd take care of her.  She wouldn't be waiting for us to find another person to take her in, I'd do it.  Not just for a while, forever.

I made the decision that I'd pay whatever it cost to give her that chance of living.

I don't get a chance to use this knowledge because I'm petting (or just holding) Chloe non-stop.

Which brings us back to where were an hour and twenty five minutes ago.

Once upon a time long ago and far away a friendly cop gave my my sister a ride; she sat in the back as, if I'm remember correctly, she thought it was cool to be there like a criminal.

She learned something: it's most comfortable if your hands are behind your back as if cuffed.

It's surprisingly spacious in the back of the car.  Walking around Chloe to sit on the non-bloody side was easy.

Not sure if it was the right call.  I can pet Chloe, I can hold Chloe, and I can certain talk to her, but she's facing away.  She can't see me.

They ask if one of us is going too, I that I am before they finish asking.

We put Chloe in the driver's side, I go around to the passenger side.  There are already drops of blood on the floor, and a puddle on the seat.  Where I was going to sit.

I sit on the passenger side.

With that wonderful thought, everyone has arrived.  One cop came because he happened to be in the area, another came because, if I understood what I overheard properly, he was sent.

I don't know why the third one came, or why that was the one to transport Chloe.

So, dog poop.

It neither looks nor smells attractive. What comes out of Chloe, though, is on another level.

I know nothing of dog digestion, but I can tell that this intensely literal shit wasn't meant to come out yet.

I've been told that, when you're dying, your bowels empty.

Cops arrive, Chloe moves and I try to tell her not to; not to exert herself.

Turns out that she had a reason entirely unrelated to the new people arriving.

Finally free of phones (I hate phones) I was back on the floor beside Chloe.  I think it was at this point she tried to lift her head, I gave her support, and that got her blood smeared across my forearm.

I do my best to comfort her.

It took a bit to explain that I just wanted the dog taken to medical care; I hadn't even paid enough attention to know whether the person who hit her fled the scene or tried to be responsible so getting someone arrested/fined/whatever they do might not even be necessary.

He, however, had an idea no one else had had: Call the police, ask for animal control, because those people know how to move animals.

It turned out that animal control wasn't available over the phone, but it also turned out they were unnecessary.
This was Friday.  My dad is not available on Friday.  She said I should call my dad because she thought he was at home.  He wasn't because, again, it was Friday and he isn't available on Friday.

Regardless, at this point my sister had already (long since) contributed everything she had to contribute, and done it in an entirely different phone call (on an entirely different phone.)

It was a vital contribution, but not remotely for the reason she thought.
The reason, by the way, that I think I knew it was my sister on the other end of the line when I said that is because otherwise I think I would have used "them" instead of "her".

Entirely regardless of what my sister's response was, I wanted house guest to be the one to hang up the phone. I feel that was unclear.

The "and hang up the phone" could have been construed as half of the message I wanted conveyed with "Fuck off" being reduced to the first half.

I was not particularly interested in the fact that my sister had taken an interest in Chloe (for the first time in God knows how long) as shown via having someone give a verbal play by play of the accident I just lived through.

I think telling her to fuck off gets that across.
In retrospect, I think that could have been clearer.

The person on the other end won't let him end the call, I tell him to screw politeness and be done with it.  The person on the other end is my sister, I think I've learned this already because I'm pretty sure I've got my diction right here, "Tell her to fuck off and hang up."

I tell him to stop again.  I probably put a "fucking" in there somewhere, but remembering my particular diction for the purpose of relaying it correctly in an eventual twitter thread is NOT my top priority right now, so I don't know for sure.

House guest starts telling someone over the phone what happened.  This is not asking, "Can you move an injured dog" and I can't deal with reliving it right now.  I tell him to stop.  I'm not particularly polite.

The person on the other end tells him to keep going.

That's not what actually happened and at some point my lack of results has reached the point where I physically double check.

Now we have three people on phones.  We can't find anyone available to transport a dog.  We don't know who to call.  I'm freaking out.

It's completely reasonable to believe that the others (housemate and a guest who's staying until traveling from Maine to New Orleans sounds like a good and safe idea again) left, told me where they were going, and I entirely forgot about the whole thing.

Phone tag and discontinued numbers and a vet who moved.  Also, I still haven't gotten the hang of dealing with heavy sleepers.  I assume that, since yelling got no response, there's no one there.

I made the same mistake when my sister was run over.

Chloe's breathing is really bad.  Weak, laborious, and sounding pretty painful.  It stops.  I legitimately think she's died in front of me.

It was just a hitch, breathing resumes.  It's the first of many, and each time I worry it'll be the one breathing doesn't resume after.

Her breathing is crap.  She can't keep her eyes all the way open.  At some point she poops.  (Not on purpose, she doesn't even move to do it.)  The aroma of dog shit hangs in the air.

Magpie has no idea what's going on.  They want to play.

The reason I'm alternating between the two is because I am worried that Chloe is going to die alone while I'm on the fucking phone.

She's gotten worse.  More blood.  Did I mention the blood before?  It comes out of her mouth, and possibly out of an eye too.

I'm on the floor with Chloe, trying to make her comfortable. Trying to comfort her. I'm on the phone desperately trying to cobble together some kind of plan.  Being out of breath doesn't help.

At some point I decide to alternate between the two instead of doing one or the other.

I send helpful person away, I think I indicate I have a plan.  I have no plan.

My exercise induced asthma has kicked in.  It never occurs to me to get my inhaler.

Everything bleeds together, the order of events is unclear.

I can't do that one handed. I ask the person who's actually treating the pandemic like a pandemic instead of… whatever. I ask them to take Magpie and bring them with me.

I pick up Chloe, we go into my house (prepared person opens the door for me) I put Chloe in the front hall.

We're in a street.  She just got hit by a car.  I'm getting her out of the street.

We're in no danger of being hit by a car --the street in question isn't like that-- she'd be fine there, I'm getting her out of the street.

When someone has been through something like that, you don't move them for no reason.

My training may be long expired, and it was intended for humans instead of dogs, but the same general principles apply. You don't just pick them up and carry them somewhere without good reason.
Someone does come eventually.  Couldn't tell you much about them.  Gloves and a mask.  They ask what they can do, have no idea, but I make a decision.  It's stupid.

I'm in the middle of my street (a residential street, not the perpendicular main street where she was hit) with one hand grabbing Magpie's collar as if everyone's life depends on me not letting go, I'm trying to comfort Chloe with the other hand, and I'm screaming for help.

There is only one situation in which Magpie isn't safe off leash.  If some stupid person lets Magpie's mom run down the street, they'll follow mom.

Chloe got hit by a car in front of her puppy.

Here's the kicker: I was holding a collar (if I'm remembering right.)

One of her pups, Magpie, is living here.  Three and a half months old and being given the early training wish Chloe had gotten.

Magpie is safe off leash, you don't need to hold on to them.
The distance from the end of the line to the house is short enough that holding her collar directly instead of via a leash is completely viable for going in and out.

That's it.

We were about a pace away from the steps to the side door, for some reason I thought she'd go up them on her own even though she never has before, so I didn't hold her collar even though that's the procedure I've always used.

All of this was because --even though I knew she'd never been properly trained and was prone to running off if unhooked outside-- I unhooked her from the line for when she's outside with me, and then didn't hold her collar.

Then she got up and ran back toward me and the house.  At least one of her legs clearly wasn't working, but it didn't slow her down.

Collapsing and coughing up blood, on the other hand, that brought her to a stop right quick.

The gofundme makes it sound like Chloe was run over like my sister had been.  It stops short of saying that, and that's good.  She wasn't run over.

She went up.  She flipped over in the air then crashed back down to earth.  I thought maybe she'd already died.
Technically, I think I made that decision well before that, and it's just that until the exam room I had something else to focus on.  Someone who I'd watched get hit by a car.

I was waiting in an empty exam room (not the waiting room, because of the pandemic) when I made a decision.

I knew talk of payment would be coming.  I'd avoided thinking of that; I don't have money to spare.

I'd pay anyway.  Even if the odds were objectively terrible.

In the back of a cop car headed to the veterinary emergency place --she was more mobile since the change of scenery, her blood on the floor, the seat, my forearm-- when I made a promise.

If she lived, I'd take care of her.  I'd find a way to make it work, depression be damned.

My sister talks about her injuries from an accident in late November than she does about the dog we're trying to save and even works in a section to try and unload the puppies she hasn't found homes for yet.

Except that's not quite true; we're not trying to save her.  I am.

This isn't against Terin, who made the gofundme.  They were great and self directed and more on top of fundraising than me by miles.

The description is dictated by my sister.  It's on her.

That said, to read the description on the gofundme, you'd think that my sister had a consistently wonderful loving relationship with Chloe.

If you weren't distracted by her making everything about herself, that is.

Now, I get that injury can set off a "You don't know what you've got till it's dying' response.

One of the people helping was talking about stopping and wanting Chloe out of her life. (Bad habits take time to unlearn.)  She had a fucking breakdown when she saw Chloe bloodied.

My sister didn't even consider she might ever want Chloe back.

The people helping me?  They've worked with problem dogs.  Chloe's been getting proper training.

My sister hasn't responded to that knowledge with, "Great, if you can make her safe, I can take her back!"
But this isn't about me, though I'll certainly make it seem like it is before I'm done.

Chloe deserves better than me.  (So does my cat, but I'm too attached to give her to someone who will be a better human to her.)  So I tried to keep my distance, emotionally speaking.

Why get attached to an animal you probably can't care for?  (At least the cat is self reliant.)

My depression is bad, I've said that often enough.  Not actively suicidal, but no real will to live.  I consistently fail to stay on top of eating, drinking, and sleeping enough.

I thought it would be cruel, and risky to keep a dog in my care long term. (Short term I have help.)

At that point my sister couldn't tell me how long I was keeping Chloe for, or if she'd ever want her back.

She could tell me that if anyone got attached, they could have her.

Eventually that became more definite: either Chloe would become my dog, or we'd find her a new home.

Putting a dog down because it tore into and severely injured another dog isn't abusive, but I think it does show a certain relationship dynamic when the owner is one "No, I can't handle a dog right now," away from going there.

That doesn't change the fact that she called me up and gave me a choice between me taking the dog and her killing the dog.

While that pisses me off and makes me prone to fucking swearing, right now I want to focus on what it says about my sister's relationship with Chloe.

To be clear, there was a reason.

There was an altercation between Chloe and the dog belonging to my sister's "it's been complicated" relationship partner (who is awesome, by the way.)  Both dogs came out of it messed up, but the other one was definitely the worse off of the two.

When Chloe came to live with me it was because of an ultimatum.  My sister called up and said, repeatedly and with more graphic language, that if I couldn't take Chloe at my house she was going to put Chloe down.

It's not like there was some competition between the names "Khloe" and "Chloe", but the dog did respond better when I said "Chloe" than when my sister said "Khloe".

That's because, while the "K" might have legal documentation backing it up, I said the name with affection.

My sister had two dogs for a long time.  They had sex as dogs are wont to do, and then she had fifteen.  Let's stick with the two adult dogs, though.

She had a clear favorite.

She didn't express that through affection towards Wash (daddy dog) so much as antipathy toward Chloe.
The long version . . . ok, there's a reason I didn't switch to writing her name as "Khloe" when I finally saw it written (after knowing her for something like a year and a half.)

@AnaMardoll Conditions improving obviously hurts those who benefited from conditions sucking in the first place, but since those people are assholes, I consider this a feature not a bug.

@AnaMardoll If everyone knows that they'll be ok whether or not they have a job, that both gives existing workers the freedom to leave toxic environments (or agitate for better conditions) and removes the supply of disposable replacement workers employers currently draw upon.

@AnaMardoll The job market is a market; it requires the same things as to function properly, and fails just as badly in their absence.

Take away worker's ability to choose who to work for, and the market breaks.  If driving away employees doesn't have negative consequences, it also breaks.

@AnaMardoll It all falls apart if the consumers can't choose to ditch bad-company in favor of less-bad-company.  It also falls apart if consumers ditching bad-company doesn't have any negative repercussions for bad-company.

In either case, bad-company has no reason to improve.

@AnaMardoll The quick and dirty version is that if a company makes a terrible product, consumers will figure out it's terrible, choose to buy from someone else, and the lost revenue will force the first company to adapt (make better products) or die.

It's pretty straightforward.

@AnaMardoll If the reason you're staying at a job is because you want to be there, you can leave if that changes.

If you need to keep that job, then no matter how bad things get you're stuck.  If everyone else is too, then workers have no power, because employers know they're trapped.

@AnaMardoll There's a massive difference between wanting a job and needing a job.

As repeatedly noted, most people want a job. It's basically the default option.

Needing a job is something else entirely. When something is necessary, you don't have a choice.

Choice, it turns out, is power.

@AnaMardoll Say you work really hard, and after five years of steady earning you become a millionaire.  You wouldn't pay taxes anywhere near the top rate.  Not near the middle rate either.

For a concrete example, the inflation adjusted 1954 tax code would have your rate in the bottom third.

@AnaMardoll Which brings us to the first people who stand to lose something.

It's not, in fact, "rich people".  It's a very specific kind of rich person.  You have to remember that we've been talking about income tax this whole time.  That changes things.

@AnaMardoll All of those years of being good at revenue collection and debt reduction mean that we don't need to choose between what works and what doesn't, but can instead choose between what works and what works better.

All of this, as noted, is solved.  It's well recorded history.

@AnaMardoll It turned out that cutting taxes on the rich while raising taxes on the middle class didn't actually work well.

That doesn't work, but it's ok because we had about thirty five years worth of examples of what does work well before that.  (And the Clinton years afterward.)

@AnaMardoll The top marginal tax rate was actually dropped, from 94% to ~86%, but after a decade that proved too low and it went back up to 91%.  Presidents came and went.  With the exception of a tiny and temporary uptick under Ford, the debt kept on going down.

Then Reaganomics.

@AnaMardoll Nowadays people would go into a complete panic about a debt that high.  (We know this because people have been panicking about a lower debt for a decade.)

At the time it was handled with rather more calm.  Taxes were fiddled with.

@AnaMardoll For one thing, things need to be paid for.  It certainly allows us to cut a lot of expensive stuff out of the budget, but I'd be very surprised if that's enough to equal the cost.

Instead, some revenue needs to be collected.  Good news, though, we already know where to get it.

@AnaMardoll At this point it might seem like I'm saying no one loses and everyone wins, and people will likely be justifiably suspicious about that.

@AnaMardoll No one drops out of the workforce, only those two groups delay entry.  That leaves you with just about the same amount of workers, they've changed, though.

When people know that they'll have enough to live on no matter what, that reduces stress allowing them do better work.

@AnaMardoll When you provide everyone with enough money to live on, students students who would otherwise have joined the workforce chose to focus on their education.

That lets you reduce dropout rates and increase test scores.  You're welcome.

@AnaMardoll As noted way back somewhere before I talked about tax codes, people don't stop working just because they can survive unemployment.

@AnaMardoll A minimum basic income also means that you've created an environment that's conducive to innovation.

In order for people to come up with great new ideas, they need time spent not having their lives dominated by the seemingly impossible task of staying alive in this economy.

@AnaMardoll It also instantly deals with a lot of other things.

For example: if everyone has enough money to live on by default, you've just solved all of our minimum wage problems.  (And you've done it without hurting business.)

@AnaMardoll Everything that I've said about this, though, goes a way in an instant if we just give people enough money to live on (with, as noted, certain safeguards.)

applies always and forever.

Let it be known, future generations, when you ask where I was when my country was doing eleventy billion terrible things at home and abroad, the answer is that I was feeling bad about failing a goat.

The goat's name is "Vivian".  I have not built her a leg.

The knee is intact (it's just not connected to much of anything) so there's only one joint to replace.  I think it's the fetlock.*  This should be simple.

I've made zero progress.

* But I know that term because I wrote My Little Pony fanfic, not My Little Capra, so maybe not.

I . . . know nothing.  I do know that while she's doing an admirable job of not just going, "Fuck it," and giving up, she doesn't exactly have the best quality of life.

Also, I feel deep pangs of guilt whenever I see her try to use the non-existent lower limb. (She always does.)

Someone somewhere knows how the joints in a prosthetic goat foreleg need to move and not move in order for a goat to walk without having their quality of life fucked over.

I'm sure that many people manywheres know good ways to secure replacement limbs to existing ones.

And the thing is, I know this is a solved problem. People know how to make goat legs. This has been done before (by people way more qualified than me.)

What I don't know is where to go for "No idea what you're doing but need to do it anyway?  Pull up a chair; I got you covered."

Neither, it should be noted, is building a leg.

Hell, I had my mind fucking blown when I realized that a goat's front knees are equivalent to a human's _wrists_, so obviously I'm not an expert on goat anatomy.

But the fact is, the goat needs a leg and somehow that's my job

It was hard keeping her still, I was half dead, and there were things to be done in the house, so I didn't manage it.

I was reminded of the fact that making things super secure in ways that won't threaten circulation is not a thing I have experience with.

I wanted to use another sock (there were unmatched socks on hand, you see) as a knee pad, because the knee of her complete foreleg has been brutalized by the way she has to kneel to eat ground-level food.

The front of the knee is just a furless patch of "That looks painful."

I'm honestly surprised the sock was still on there today, it was a very quick slapdash thing.

Sort of, "I still haven't made you a leg, and you're still suffering, but I can surreptitiously appropriate a toddler's sock for you and tie it on, so I can pretend I'm being useful."

Every time I go to help my sister I swear my body falls apart a little more. Pretty sure I've done more than could reasonably be expected in every way but one.

I need to build a goat leg. Also a knee pad.

Vivan has had 3.5 legs for forever, only got a sock on her nub yesterday.

And now, after spending the day with my mom, I have an update.

https://t.co/TfR5jEgjla

The short, short version is basically:
I'm pretty sure that the things that she knows and I don't are all leaning strongly toward the 'things will be ok' end of the spectrum.
(Everything I said about finances, depression, feeling guilty, and so forth still applies, of course.)
It seems like things are probably about as good as they can be given all that, which is _not_ the impression I was left with this morning.

I mean, my mom is still going into surgery in two days, and there are definitely risks, and as far as I know my sister's description was factually accurate, and it's never good when your doctor says, "It looks like we need to remove part of your body," BUT . . .

Based on the way my mom was acting today, my sister should have introduced topic with, "This is going to sound really terrible, but it almost certainly isn't."

There's a reason that, when we all lived in the same house, I served as translator.

How do I know she's not just putting on a brave face?  Go back a few tweets.

How do I know that this isn't her being optimistic in the face of bad news?  Ditto.

So, basically, what I learned is that from her perspective everything is fine.

That in turn means that, medically, things are definitely on the "Other than the conditions that necessitate this surgery, everything looks pretty good" side of things.

It's like, for literally anyone else I'd be one of the first to point out that the conclusions don't necessarily follow from the premise, but for her I know they do, and that's not in a way that I'd ever be able to communicate in tweets.

What my sister told me this morning is still the vast majority of what I've been directly told.

What I've learned since then comes from spending much of the day around my mom and —this is where words fail me— knowing her well enough to turn that into pretty distant conclusions.
The reason I'm having so much damned trouble coming up with the words to say this is that everything's sort of roundabout.

So I have an update on what's happening with my mother, but I'm having difficulty finding the right words.

Short version: things appear to be a lot better than they seemed this morning.

But that's not the point.  The point is that I had to say something to someone.

And now I have double check that I'm ready; she'll be here soon.

Now she's having part of her body cut out of her because apparently she's got something that looks enough like cancer to justify an -ectomy.

But that's entirely beside the current point.

The current point is that my mother has done so very much for me, at a fairly large psychological toll (in stress) to herself, it's hard to feel like I've done anything but take advantage of her, and now . . .
I just realized that I've been taking the wrong dose of something for what must be ages at this point.  (Not my primary antidepressant, that would be too obvious.)  So that's doubtless played a roll.

I've done the math --we did the math beforehand for fuck's sake-- and I should be able to make the payments we agreed on with no problem.  I just . . . don't.

Honestly not sure where the money even goes, though some of is almost certainly late fees for creditors less forgiving.

I'm going to have to go back through my records to find out how much I owe her, but it's definitely over $10,000 by now.

I feel absolutely terrible about that.  She's always completely stressed out about money, she's spent so much of it to help me, and I'm not doing my part.
Note that when she gave me an interest free loan to pay off thousands of dollars in credit card debt _I_was_already_ in a state of failing to pay my regular bills to her on time.

That's with the understanding that I still have to pay eventually, but on the "have to pay eventually" front, my mom gave me a loan to pay off all my credit card debt late last year.

Her loan was and is interest free.  That's a huge difference.

In practice I haven't paid her since my depression went from "Way worse than usual" to "Oh my God!  What the fuck‽" about a year ago.

(Right now I'm in a state of "It's like I'm not even taking my meds . . . fuck, Fuck, FUCK!")

Though, in the interest of complete accuracy and honesty, the fact that there were black people in Europe tells us little about the Europe-adjacent half-fish population, especially given their isolationist policies.

They could have all been a uniform shade of purple.

If you really want to get hung up on historical inaccuracies, focus on the fork.

https://t.co/b5yxzlnMeK

So, if you should be making a hyper-realistic historically accurate movie about about people who are half fish and also ~something~something~ Europe, please do remember that there were black people in Europe.

At this point we're firmly into really fucking modern history.  Many historians would disagree and claim we're just barely into modern history, but --either way-- knowledge of modern history will show that there were, and are, black people in Europe.

Now then, it turns out that that thing that I linked to is way more awesome than the name suggests, because it'll take you into and beyond the Renaissance and Reformation.

As you can probably guess, one thing you will learn is that there were black people in Europe back then.
It's probably passed time that I address the fact that I've been focusing on black people and not people of color in general.  It's because this is about The Little Mermaid.  No other reason.

After the Romans come the medieval times.  As a classicist, these times are outside of my area.  Fortunately, this (https://t.co/tLiAikZELn) exists so you can go there and learn about the fact that there were black people in Europe then too.

So let's talk Romans.  The Roman Republic (509 BC to 27 BC) had black people in it.  Yes, even in Europe.

The Roman Empire, (27 BC to 480 AD in the west and 1453 AD in the east) started off as "The Republic, under new management" so, as you'd expect, it also had black people.

Now the Etruscan civilization may have endured to circa 100 BC, but when it reached that point they weren't so much "The strongest power in Italy" as "That one city the Romans haven't gotten around to taking from the Etruscans yet."

Ok, so, apparently The Little Mermaid (Disney, not Hans Christian Andersen) is an intellectual property that was and is firmly based in historical realism.  Apparently.

So, let's talk history.  Once upon a time (~900 BC to ~100 BC) there were Etruscans.  Some were black.

@AnaMardoll Other than following the rule "If at all possible, try not to be an asshole," none of the ways of practicing mainstream Roman religion were open to Christians.

@gi66le_tits @AnaMardoll That's what I recall from my college days as well.

@AnaMardoll By the time of persecution, Christians were poly-cultural.  They had no unified cultural history, which meant that they couldn't have a mos maiorum to follow.

Christians weren't sacrificing, they didn't yet have a body of ritual, they didn't have temples.

@AnaMardoll The only place what it meant to be pious Christian and what it meant to be a pious Roman overlapped was that serving the divine included just action.

The rest of the things Romans did to serve their gods weren't possible for Christians.

@AnaMardoll So for mainstream Romans, "If you say you're not a Christian, then you can go and serve your Christian God," seemed like an easy choice.

But the Christians didn't have a mos maiorum to follow, and they didn't have a temple to worship in, they had an idea and a message.

@AnaMardoll A pious Roman would follow the mos maiorum, honor their ancestors, and please the gods with ritual (including sacrifice) and just action.

Nowhere in there does it say, "Be honest about your religious convictions at all times at all costs."

@AnaMardoll With the giant caveat that we don't know about mystery religions, that made perfect sense in the Roman religious mindset.  The important things were what you did, not what you said.

(Sometimes, of course, the two overlap.)

@AnaMardoll There were Romans who persecuted Christians who didn't understand why the fuck it was happening.  Another letter whose citation I've forgotten described how a Roman tried to explain, "You just have to _say_ these are your beliefs, you don't have to believe them," and saw it fail.

@AnaMardoll Socrates got himself killed because he refused to, even for a moment, break with his beliefs.  He wouldn't say he didn't believe.  That's a very philosopher thing to do.

Mainstream Roman religion wasn't into that.  If lying will allow you to do your religious duties, you lied.
@AnaMardoll That's a really important distinction because it changed the fundamental understanding of one's relationship with the divine.

@AnaMardoll There was also a fundamental disconnect between Christians and mainstream Romans.  Christians would tell you that what they were doing was a religion, but it didn't _look_ like a religion to the Romans.

It hewed closer to philosophy given their understanding of the two fields.

@AnaMardoll That being said, for most of the period during which Christianity was illegal, in most parts of the empire, the persecution was of the form "pretend you're in the closet so I can pretend I don't notice."

That's horrible, but it's not the narrative modern Christians tend to tell.

@AnaMardoll This isn't to say that Christians weren't persecuted, because they were.  And persecution had a huge effect upon Christianity.  Nero scapegoating them is hugely important in the history of Christianity because it's what cemented "Christianity" as "not-Judaism".

@AnaMardoll The ichthus (Christian fish) is a great example of that in practice.  Christians came up with a symbol that wasn't obviously Christian, everyone else pretended they didn't know what it meant, everybody won.

@AnaMardoll There's a letter (don't remember which letter, from whom, or to whom, and I'm unlikely to bump into it again) where a Roman administrator flat out asks another, "What should I do about these Christians?" and the response is just that: ignore them; pretend you don't notice.

But mostly it's just:

We churn out games where the protagonists don't speak in-game, but in every such game I've encountered they do speak (just not in-game), because Heaven forfend that non-speaking characters might actually give representation to non-speaking people.

Also, personally, I would identify more if a character responded to others via ASL, a language I have utterly failed to learn multiple times, than I do with the characters who never acknowledge others (because the devs fear that if I hear their voice, I won't identify with them.)

Apparently about .08 percent of the population is born unable to speak, I'm guessing that the potion of the population who would, for example, survive fighting hordes of aliens singlehandedly is rather smaller.  Ditto for most of the premises in such games.
The point is that, given how many games star characters who _don't_ speak, it's absurd (and fucking wrong) that we don't have a ton of games staring characters who _can't_ speak.
Now, making the protagonist unable to speak would defeat half of the reasoning behind making silent protagonists in otherwise voiced games in the first place, but that's the not point here.
In all of my time playing as characters who never say a god-damned word, I don't think I've ever played (or seen) a video game with a mute player character.

So, yesterday I finished playing Aliens vs. Predator (2010) (probably for the 2nd time) and today I was on a long car ride, in which I could only hear wind and my thoughts, to get home from helping my sister on her farm.

This led to reflection on silent video game protagonists.
