And I feel like this is, in some way that I can't really describe, a sharp contrast to farm work.

It's a sense that, even if I tried, I couldn't get further from farm work than:

"Must find last collectible in this level!" --> "Woo! I'm climbing the ladder on a fictional tower!"
Anyway, that scene is, quite possibly, the most epic ladder climbing scene in the history of video games.

Though, part of that could just be that I've never actually invested in having a soundtrack.

Both times I did the Knife Edge on Katahdin, for example, the acoustic accompaniment was my mother and I talking to one another, not some moving instrumental score.

For those of you who have neither played nor viewed the 2013 incarnation of Tomb Raider, climbing that tower is more epic and scenic than anything not involving four to eight hours of hiking has any right to be.

After the call and agreeing to do the farm work, I went back to that video game, needlessly subjected myself to more frustration, and found that damned GPS cache.

Then I climbed the giant tower.

The feedback that an electric fence gives you is a very basic "warmer"/"colder" kind of feedback (and if it's zapping more strongly here than there, _something_ is going on between those two points) but that's more than most games will give you when hunting down collectibles.
Also the electric fence is something where you can legitimately check the whole thing end to end without missing what you're looking for fifteen times in a row, and it even has a degree of feedback.

Except the electric fence thing involves less spamming focus and more zapping yourself (general rule: if the charge is too strong for a person to willing subject themselves to, don't use it to tell mid-sized furry animals, 'No, I'd rather you _not_ try to circumvent that fence.')

But, on the other hand, part of the fencing we'll be doing is electric, and finding where you've accidentally grounded that stuff can feel like looking for the last GPS cache in Tomb Raider's "Mountain Base" section amidst the bad-wiring sparks that look like the GPS cache blink.

Because I was deep in the middle of that when the call came asking me if I could spend my tomorrow working on fences at the farm (home to Lola the pig, Vivian the 3.5 legged goat, plus another goat, two sheep, and a veritable horde of chickens and ducks whose names I know not.)

You could look it up online, but you don't _want_ to look it up online, especially since this is a small level so, you feel, you should be able to get this done.

You could just come back to it later, and go climb the giant radio tower, but you want to get this shit done _first_.

So, you know that feeling when you think you've finally found the second (and last) GPS cache in the mountain base after running around fucking everywhere spamming the "focus" function constantly, only to realize that it's just faulty wiring sparking?

But the thing is, it's not all sunshine and lollipops.  (Or was that "Rainbows and ice cream?)  Anyway, not all [that thing], in part because there's a lot that goes into a game like that other than true love and gratuitous violence.

That's especially true given that "Sam was recently involved in an attempted soul transfer with an immortal, which may have had aftereffects" is at least as compelling of a motivation for Lara seeking the truth behind myths of immortality as "Lara's dad had an obsession."
Much could be written about how the sequel suffered for replacing the motivation of "Lara loves Sam and will do whatever it takes to save her" with "Lara has daddy issues.  Hard."

The "one true love" bit is what sells it by the way.  Without the affection between Lara and Sam, it'd basically just be:

Lara Croft gets a literal boatload of people into mortal peril, kills hundreds in her efforts to get them back out of it, all but three die anyway.

And it is, of course, a fairy tale.

A young scholar, fresh from her schooling, is forced to become a warrior in order to save her one true love --a lost and forgotten princess who was raised as a peasant-- from an evil cult leader and an (also evil) undead queen.

I was playing through some of Tomb Raider (2013), something which is good in many ways.  For example, while you _know_ that it's a story about Lara saving her girlfriend (word used in the non-Platonic sense) Sam when you're not playing, you don't _feel_ it in full.

So, the short, short version my my Spider-Man: Far From Home commentary is:

This movie wants to tell a story that's impossible in the post-Endgame world, but it insists it exists in exactly that world.  Why?

For the longer version, click through. https://t.co/NsM25N4uua
I ask because I don't remember the last time it felt like being part of the MCU continuity was lifting a film up instead of weighing it down.

What's the last MCU movie that actually benefited from being in a shared universe?

If they'd just said, "Yes, we're (mostly) using the same familiar face for each character, but don't expect everything to line up," what would have been lost?

So, instead, we're getting a movie that doesn't follow Endgame.  And that's fine.  But why, then, are we being told that it does?  Why not just say, "This is a different continuity"?

You don't need continuity to have the same actors show up as the same characters, after all.

I don't particularly want a "Spider-Man and His Amazing Friends have all their joy and optimism crushed in the famine-ridden Hellscape that necessarily follows Endgame" movie.

I understand why they're not doing it.

But that's the only Spider-Man movie that can follow Endgame.

Which, in the end, is sort of the problem with the MCU.

They wanted a connected universe.  They refused to connect it.

Every damned movie they set up things that must necessarily happen, or be true, or have consequences, and every time they ignored it as completely as possible.

Nothing in what's been released about the movie even attempts to address anything that happened in Endgame other than, "Hey, we're fresh out of Iron Man."

We know beyond all doubt that the world is falling apart in the worst possible way; Peter Parker goes on vacation.

No matter how hard they try, there is no possible way that they can avoid being completely swept up in this global disaster.

Until the food supply and population reach equilibrium this will be their lives.

They will be forever changed by it.

We aren't likely to see that.

Remember, there has never in history been a situation where there were twice as many people as the food supply could support.  Like the snap, this is superlative.

This is the worst famine *ever*.  It's the first worldwide one, too.

Peter and Pals are in NYC: front row seating.

We aren't likely to see Peter and friends facing food riots or the government response.

We aren't likely to see the effect of the political instability that would necessarily exist even if this weren't happening a mere five years after the worst disaster in history.

We can imagine it because it's the kind of scene that has to happen in Spider-Man: Far From Home if it's actually part of the post-Endgame MCU.

We can also say, with a fair degree of certainty, that nothing like it will appear.

Any animal goes, so we can imagine a scene where Spider-Man races to the scene of a major disturbance and discovers that it's not normal criminals or supervillains; it's just a crowd of hungry people who have decided that the NYPD horses and dogs are a viable food source.

It's not like pets are the only thing, of course.  Given where he lives, you can bet that Peter's diet is going to include rats and pigeons for a while.

They'll run low, of course.  They're in the middle of a famine too, and humans outnumber them.  But, for a while . . .

There are going to be tough questions for students at Peter's high school.

Questions like, "Would I rather eat Fluffy, or Spot?" and, "Do I have it in me to butcher them myself, or will I need to get someone else --who would take some of the meat as payment-- to do it?"

Long before we reach the point of cannibalism, we get people eating every non-human in sight.

Good news is that the food Peter Parker eats is probably produced by humans and machines, so this won't lead to a decrease in production for him.

Bad news: pets will be on the menu.

There are, of course, other ways to approach the problem.  One is expanding what one considers food.  We've already mentioned that, to a degree, in the form of people eating seed stock.  That's only one part of it.

One solution to more mouths to feed than the food can support is the Thanos solution: fewer mouths to feed.

Genocide is a very real possibility, but there's also less sinister things.  People will refuse to eat (and thus starve to death) so that there's more food for others.

Until there's a harvest large enough to feed everyone left alive, you're kind of screwed.  There's a major threat to that harvest.

Those seeds you need to plant to make that harvest?  They're food you could use to keep your family alive.  Do that, and there's nothing to plant.

One reason that famine sucks so much, by the way, is that no amount of pulling together or cooperation can compensate for there not being enough calories to go around.

If you're eating the minimum necessary for survival and using all the food, there's nothing more you can do

Given time, the extra people can do extra work on extra agriculture to make extra food.  Given time.

In the immediate aftermath, however, we're talking about the worst famine in recorded history.

When the carrying capacity is lower than the population, you get famine.

Usually this happens because something happened to the food supply (crop failures, for example) but suddenly doubling the number of mouths to feed will very definitely do the job.

Now, obviously, we're going to see a lot of killing and whatnot over other things, but food is what I want to concentrate on.

Carrying capacity isn't a set thing.  It changes.  Notably, it drops to match a reduced population.  Five years is more than enough time for that drop.

The world isn't ready for these new people.

There have not been five years of preparation for, "Ok, about 3.75 billion people are going to pop into existence out of nowhere, so we need to make sure we have food, shelter, infrastructure, and employment for all of them waiting."

We have a universe that's only five years removed from the greatest disaster in the history of the universe, and it just got slammed with a new one.

For Spider-Man, we're concerned with earth.  That's good because we understand earth.

Caveats:
https://t.co/ycP70zpuVu

Just saw an ad for Spider-Man: Far From Home, and it looks like it's ignoring the premise.  Hard.

The premise, remember, is that the population of the universe in general, and earth in particular, just doubled* without warning.

*Caveats aplenty, we'll link to them.

We can't really answer that.  We don't know how many died in the disruption.  We don't know if people have been breeding like rabbits.

It's almost certainly the case that the population doubled or more than doubled with the unsnap, but which of those it did is harder to say.

Anyway, all of that is why it's difficult to say whether "doubled" is accurate.

Half of the population disappears.  A bunch more die.  Time passes.  The population is now [something].  The people who disappeared reappear.  Many die.  Is the population now ≈ 2 x [something]?

This also, by the way, is Flight of the Navigator.

David couldn't fit into a world where eight years had passed while he remained the same.

David, of course, had it comparatively easy.  He was the only one to disappear, so there was no major disruption to life on earth.

Which brings us back to the suicides.

The world they knew is gone, the new world doesn't have a place for them, they don't know the first thing about making a place, some of the people they care about are dead, others are so very different.

The psychological strain is high.

Certainly reconnection is possible, but in the face of people who have lived (and grown) five years through Hell in what was, to them, the blink of an eye, the unsnapped are going to have a hard time relating.

Those who returned have to face that.  They also have to face the fact that everyone they knew who lived through it is fundamentally changed.

Other than the ones snapped and unsnapped with them, the people they once knew are gone.  Some died, the rest are different people now.

A lot of the non-snapped people they knew will be dead because of the aftermath.  Be it the immediate disaster or the riots or the wars or --and this one is brutal-- because they stopped receiving the care a snapped individual had been providing, a lot of the nonsnapped are dead.

The people who burst back into being are going to have to be faced with the fact that the world as they knew it ended, and there's this new thing in its place that they don't understand, don't fit into, and are ill equipped to cope with.

That's before we get to the people.

Every recorded war pales in comparison to the inevitable after-snap conflict.  All wars combined wouldn't measure up.

Before, alongside, and after that is the political maneuvering and restructuring.

When the bodies are buried and borders settled, earth will be unrecognizable.

Which brings us to the wars and riots and so forth.

This is when you begin to understand precisely why the filmmakers curled up into a ball, whimpered, and finally gave the fuck up --instead opting to push it off screen with a time-skip-- in the face of what they'd created.

It doesn't actually take that much to collapse a civilization; what Thanos did was more than enough to collapse every civilization. In fact, if that had been his goal, we would be well justified in calling what he did massive, absurdly over the top, overkill.

But, again, for every person in an inopportune place, more weren't.

They, of course, had to then deal with the biggest disruption in human history.

Most visions of the Rapture are lighter and fluffier.  In real history, the Black Death wasn't nearly so terrible.

Those people who would later appear in the middle of the road?  They were on the road.  It probably doesn't matter whether they're driver or passenger, since a passenger going dust is going to distract the driver.

So on, so forth.

Five years ago, no caveats, half the population of the universe disappeared.

We're primarily concerned with earth, and even then we limit ourselves to humans instead of talking about ecosystem collapse or intestinal bacteria, so for us it's really more that ~3.75 billion humans.

Kicking someone five years into the future would be a strain normally, but this isn't just any future.

Five years ago something happened, and the snapped back people are going to be hit with the full reality of that all at once and it's going to _hurt_.

Which brings us to the psychological toll.

A lot of people are going to be visiting their own (empty) graves and wondering if that's how it was meant to be, and (whether they do that or not) not everyone is going to survive thinking along those lines.

We could obviously go on at great length, but it's important to note that for all of the people who suddenly find themselves off belay in mid air, or in the middle of the ocean with no boat, there are more who appear in places where they're safe and sound, physically at least.

A more pressing concern is probably those who appeared in the middle of roads.  Over nine million would have done this in the US alone.  That's going to lead to secondary die off, in the form of everyone who gets offed in the traffic accidents.

Some of the people popping into existence are doing it less than idea places.  Think "a bowl of petunias and a very surprised looking whale" places.

Well over three hundred thousand would have appeared at airplane cruising altitudes sans plane, for example.

So, I was writing a thread on Spiderman: Far From Home and how it seems to be ignoring its own premise, and I realized that I needed a separate thread on the caveats to the statement that the premise is "The population just doubled without warning."

So, caveats here.

Trump/"We've always been a war with Eastasia":

Step Three:

Now that you've eliminated the biggest causes of opioid abuse (and made the country a better place for everyone as a side effect) reexamine the problem to determine what the remaining causes are and how they might be addressed without hurting/killing people.

Step Two: Deal with poverty.

We were winning the war on poverty until we stopped fighting it.  I wasn't actually born yet back then, but (shockingly) records of America before Reagan still survive to this day.  History is not lost to us.

The quickest thing is to get everyone insurance (remember when we were actually trying to do that?) and increase fucking Medicaid funding so that doctors will actually take it.

The longer harder part is changing the culture so that doctors actually prescribe what's necessary.

Want to fix the opioid problem?

Step one: Make sure everyone has access to doctors who will actually prescribe them the medications they need, so that they don't have to buy illegal shit and hope for the best,

(continued)

It takes but a glance to see that some of the biggest causes of said-epidemic are:
-- Uninsured people self-medicating badly.
-- People on Medicaid self-medicating badly.
-- Poverty in general

All of these have obvious solutions, not one of which is restricting access to meds.

Instead of doing things that would have no effect on the opioid epidemic, but hurt and kill the people she says she's trying not to effect, she could actually look at the problem and try to craft solutions that work.

So, what I like about Warren as a potential president is not just the places where she's already morally correct, knowledgeable, and absurdly qualified.  It's also that, unlike a lot of would-be leaders, I actually believe that she can get there in the areas where she isn't.

People who think they already have all the answers are dangerous.  People who think they've got everything right and don't have room for improvement should be avoided, or at least given a wide berth.

Unfortunately, a lot of such people are politicians.

(continued)

When she fucks up, as human beings are wont to do, she's shown the capacity to learn and change and grow.  It's not instant, and sometimes it includes a train-wreck of fail first, but the ability to say "Oops, I fucked up" (mea culpa) is incredibly important.

(continued)

Back on Warren, there are many good things to bring up (and listening her describe first learning stories of how people went bankrupt is incredibly moving (if absolutely heartbreaking)), but there's something I don't tend to hear about that matters a lot too.

(continued)

I had to stop following politics ages ago for mental health reasons.  (My depression is bad enough on its own; reminders that we're in an unrealistically over the top dystopia don't help.)

As such, I have anxiety that the world changed and everything I say is wrong.

(continued)

So, I saw something about Bernie Sanders, which naturally made me think about Elizabeth Warren.

I've wanted her to be president forever.  When she first ran for Senate I was worried that she' be too busy being a first term Senator to run for president in 2016.

(continued)

I've never really understood the appeal of such stories and tend to avoid them, but after reading what the fandom has to offer in terms of trans characters, I feel like I need "Trans character shows up, is accepted with ease, and does regular character stuff" as a counterpoint.

For the first time in my life I found myself wanting the kind of of self-indulgent fanfic where an original character shows up out of nowhere, is befriended by the main cast for no discernible reason, and hangs out with them over the course of their adventures.

(continued)

There's one notable example where the main character is allowed to do things beyond (in her case) being discovered as trans.  It hits the first and second points so hard that it ends with her martyrdom.

At about that point that I kind of hit critical nope.

(continued)

The natural consequence of the first and second thing is that you don't really get to see trans* characters doing ... much of anything really.

They come out or get found out and then, more often than not, the story ends. Outside of that one moment, they don't exist.

(continued)

Second, they tend to be weighty as fuck.  One of the lighter fluffier ones takes place after the main character has been ostracized by their original friends and family due to their transition.

Again: that's notably lighter and fluffier than the norm.

(continued)

First off, all of those stories are about _being_ trans*.

For comparison, there are almost no stories about being a lesbian.  Instead there are stories about adventure, or romance, or simply living life that have lesbians as characters in them.

(continued)

With my creativity showing signs that it might shamble zombie-like back into the world typically reserved for the living, I find myself revisiting an idea I had a while back after reading through the scant few stories with trans* characters on Fimfiction.

(continued)

Given that it's November now, and I'm from the US, I'll point to this again.

If you can vote, I very much encourage you to vote.

If you are able to vote it means that no one has managed to take that power from you (and people _are_ trying), please don't just give it up. https://t.co/RFj0owMhg1

If you can vote, that's a power that hasn't been taken from you yet.  Use it.

The reason that certain people are trying so hard to take that right away from so many is because it still matters.

One of the dangers of feeling powerless is that you can stop believing in whatever power you do have, however small. Since you don't believe that power is real, you don't use it, and through that choice you strip yourself of what little was left after outside forces took the rest
If you're from the US, as I am, then you know what it's like to feel completely powerless as everything goes to Hell around you.
